Only 35 affordable and available rental homes exist for every 100 extremely low-income
renter households nationally. As a result:
● 75% of extremely low-income renters are severely cost-burdened (spending more than
50% of income on housing)
● 87% spend more than 30% of income on housing
● Extremely low-income renters account for over two-thirds of all severely cost-burdened
households despite representing only a quarter of all renters
Mississippi's Housing Landscape
Mississippi performs relatively better than many states but still faces significant challenges:
Mississippi Housing Shortage Statistics:
● 102,509 extremely low-income renter households statewide
● 59 affordable homes per 100 extremely low-income households (ranking among the
better-performing states nationally)
● 66% of extremely low-income renters are severely cost-burdened
● Only states like North Dakota (62 per 100) and West Virginia (58 per 100) perform
marginally better
Mississippi vs. National Context: While Mississippi's ratio of 59 affordable units per 100
households exceeds the national average of 35, significant gaps remain. Even in the
"best-performing" state (North Dakota), 38% of extremely low-income households lack affordable
housing options.
Hattiesburg Market Dynamics
Current Rental Market Conditions:
● Average rent ranges from $917-$1,160 monthly (varying by source and date)
● Studio apartments: $1,160 average
● One-bedroom apartments: $917-$950 average
● Two-bedroom apartments: $1,084 average
● Three-bedroom apartments: $1,479 average
